title: 110_s2065
content: The Act titled "Community Coalitions for Access and Quality Improvement Act of 2007" is established for the purpose of improving access and quality in communities. The Act aims to assist community health coalitions in improving access to and quality of healthcare services through coordination, infrastructure development, and activities related to providing comprehensive care. The Act aims to assist community health coalitions in improving access to and quality of healthcare services through coordination and activities related to providing comprehensive care for individuals with chronic conditions. SEC. 3. COMMUNITY COALITIONS FOR ACCESS AND QUALITY IMPROVEMENT. Grants are awarded to eligible entities to develop integrated health care delivery systems for defined communities, aiming to improve efficiency, coordination among providers, prevent chronic diseases, and expand services. Eligible entities must represent a balanced consortium focused on sustainable capacity provision. The eligible entities must develop integrated health care delivery systems for defined communities, including a range of coordinated services and specific healthcare providers like federally qualified health centers and rural health clinics. The eligible entities for developing integrated health care delivery systems include networks, hospitals with a low-income utilization rate, Critical Access Hospitals, public health departments, and interested health care providers or organizations serving the uninsured and low-income individuals. Eligible entities for integrated health care delivery systems must submit an application to the Secretary with details on the community to be served, providers involved, proposed activities, and evidence of eligibility. The applicant must demonstrate an established coalition with the ability to involve providers who have traditionally served uninsured and low-income individuals in the community. They must also show the ability to develop coordinated systems of care that provide a broad range of high-quality services, ensuring continuity of care. The coalition must show evidence of community involvement, ability to enroll individuals in health care coverage programs, plan for leveraging other revenue sources, and a plan for evaluation of activities to ensure long-term sustainability of the system of care. The eligible entity must demonstrate fiscal responsibility, commitment to serving the community regardless of ability to pay, and provide evidence of evaluation plans for program improvement. The initial grant term is limited to 3 fiscal years. The eligible entity may receive a grant extension for up to 2 additional years if the Secretary deems it necessary to further the objectives of the program. Priorities for grant awards include addressing unmet community needs and promoting program objectives effectively. The applicant must identify a community with a high percentage of uninsured or low-income individuals, include providers with a history of serving this population, and expand access to preventive and primary care services for uninsured and underinsured individuals and families. The applicant must demonstrate collaboration with State and local governments, use non-Federal contributions to the greatest extent possible, and show likelihood of proposed activities leading to sustainable integrated delivery systems. Grantees are required to use funds provided for specified purposes, with exceptions outlined in the grant agreement. Grantees must use funds for direct expenses related to integrating a healthcare delivery system and expanding patient care services within the system. Grantees may use funds for outreach activities, closing gaps in healthcare services, improving patient-centered care, coordinating transportation to healthcare facilities, and developing provider networks. The curr_chunk discusses the development of provider networks, recruitment of personnel, acquisition of technology for care coordination, and common processes for healthcare programs. The curr_chunk discusses the facilitation of community organizations to improve access to high-quality healthcare services for individuals with chronic diseases or cancer, including language access services and overcoming barriers within the healthcare system. The curr_chunk focuses on the allocation of funds for direct patient care, national program purposes, and specific requirements related to grants for improving healthcare services for individuals with chronic diseases or cancer. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for entities receiving grants under this section, including submitting annual reports on progress towards goals and measurable objectives, improving services for uninsured and low-income individuals, and using outcome measures to assess effectiveness. Entities receiving grants under this section must provide better quality healthcare to the community at a lower cost, as evidenced by independent financial audits. The Secretary can only renew grants if reasonable progress towards goals is demonstrated. Entities receiving grants under this section must maintain their non-Federal expenditures at or above the previous fiscal year's level. The Secretary can provide technical assistance to grant recipients to help them meet the requirements of the program. The Secretary will evaluate the success of projects funded under this section in improving services and healthcare quality while reducing costs. Authorization of appropriations is set at $75 million for 2008, $100 million for 2009, and $125 million for 2010. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2010, 2011, and 2012 are set at $125,000,000, $150,000,000, and $175,000,000 respectively.
